title: When will the World Health Organization (WHO) report more than 20 million confirmed cases of COVID-19 for the South-East Asia Region?
preds: should show up in the numbers tomorrow
Rapid rise in cases in India makes it virtually certain that 20 million will be reached in a day or two
I did not realize WHO'S  southEAST region included India.
The unexpected spike in cases will probably total more than a million in the next month or so.
Counting around ~21M cases by end of April
Guess I should have payed more attention to this one. Thought it was a done deal until I checked today.

4 scenarios possible (each +/- 1 day): 1) Linear from now on: 26 April
2) Continuous growth like in the past weeks (most likely): 25 April
3) Starting flattening today with small decrease over the next days: 27 April
4) India stops testing forever before 24 April: bins 4 and 5.

At the current pace, and starting at 17.176mn cases as of 16 April, South East Asia region will exceed 20mn confirmed cases of SARS-CoV-2 on 27 April. However,
/it is very likely that daily new cases of India will peak soon and will peak before 30 April 2021
/will, after its peak, decline by 15 to 25% over the course of two weeks (i.e. to 160k to 185k, if today is the peak). If this reduction starts immediately, India's contribution to SE Asia total could be limited to 2.66 to 2.7mn new cases in the best case before 01 May 2021. I don't rely on a continued escalation in India yet, and leave a door open for reversal, if signs come soon and significant.
https://www.covid19india.org/ This is done. Prepared to go to 100% tomorrow.
We will be close to the required average for bin 3 for the first time tomorrow. Only a few days left, but still exponential. Poor Indians.

Update 4/14: Cases for the next week are already baked in, and they're growing exponentially. I doubt we'll see an actual decline in cases/day after that, but even if we see case growth slow, SE Asia will still reach 20M before the end of the month. It's over. A slightly conservative forecast of unabated case growth of 8.5%/day gives the following cases/day for India; actual cases exhibit a lot of day to day variability. Please note that this forecast assumes only that previous growth continues. Adding in today's WHO total and a slightly conservative 10k cases/day for all other countries in the region gives a forecast for SE Asia totals, as well.

4/26: done Cases/day towards the end of my forecast are lower than my predictions, while the percent positive on tests in India has been rising. Testing capabilities seem to be overtaxed, and my assessment of the rate of growth was too high.

Update. Case growth in this region is currently overwhelmingly driven by India. Maharashtra, which has more cases/day than any other state, won't make a decision about whether to impose a lockdown until after April 14, and even then, they will give people "enough time to prepare before lockdown is imposed." Meanwhile, migrant workers are leaving Maharashtra and going all over the country, potentially seeding new outbreaks. In addition, 30 to 50 million people from all over India are expected to attend the Kumbh Mela Hindu festival that started yesterday and is occurring over the coming month at the Ganges River at Haridwar. It's largely outdoors, but there are still plenty of opportunities for the virus to spread indoors related to this festival.  If Maharashtra imposed a serious lockdown immediately on April 15, reaching 20M cases could possibly be averted, but barely. But if Maharashtra waits a week until, say, April 22, given that it takes people who are infected an average of 5 or 6 days to develop symptoms, then I don't see how 20M will be avoided. Moreover, Maharashtra recorded 63k cases today, while India as a whole recorded 169k; Maharashtra only accounts for 37% of India's cases. I don't see the sorts of lockdowns occurring in other locations that would be needed to slow this train down before April 30. On the current trajectory, 20M cases will be reached several days before the end of this month (approx. April 25 or 26, in 13 or 14 days from now). I think just about the only way 20M won't be reached is if testing capacity is saturated in relevant parts of India, but that doesn't seem likely right now.

16.18m now
Rate for last week was 1m
So less than 3 weeks looks likely.  End of April, early may.  Probably end April if rates keep increasing.

4 weeks ago this looked like "boring, bin 5 for sure". Now it´s on "daily update required to see, if it will be bin 3 or 4". Holy cow. Wild ride.
I promise to never ever again start any question, that could even remotely be  involved with Covid-19 in India.
It will be either last week of April or 1st week of May.

Superexponential also outside of Maharashtra. Frightening.

Maharashtra no longer exponential  - I hope.
SE-Asia - India - Maharshtra. That´s, where this will resolve. Last year that province blasted my last question on GJP 2.0 -Covid up on the very last day of that question then. Will be more careful this time...

Update: still an extremely tight forecast, but SE Asia, whose numbers are currently overwhelmingly dominated by India, is still on track to reach 20M a couple days before the end of April. As more time goes on, the forecast becomes more certain.

With India the main driver of events, at the current rate, 20 million cases will be reached in the second week of July. Should India's case numbers continue to rise, the mark will be reached before July.
India is totally out of control. Expecting the daily new cases to reach 200-400k in India alone over next couple of weeks

Revised estimate.  belikewater has convinced me that a large spike in the short term, driven by cases in India (https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/india?country=IND~BGD~BTN~MDV~MMR~NPL~LKA~THA~TLS~IDN), is much more likely that I'd thought.  I still think the slower outcome is more probable because people / countries respond to sudden spikes.
Update: The forecast is still on track for 20M before April 30 (April 29, currently), but it is extremely tight. 20M could easily be reached by the first week of May.

Currently about 15 million cases and increasing by about a million a month, so a linear estimate would put it at 20 million around the beginning of September.  Could be sooner if it spikes again (or reporting methodology changes).  Very unlikely before June regardless.
5m to go.  Current rate 250k per week.  4 weeks to may would be 1m so not before May.  12 weeks to July which gives 3m.  But cases rising slightly.  Most likely July, some could be June.

Update. A closer look at the WHO numbers makes the forecast that 20M will be reached at the end of April (4/26) more secure to me. Some uncertainty from a variety of origins, and close to the edge, though.

13.3 weeks until July 1. Need to average less than 393k cases per week to stay under 20 million by July 1. The week of 3/22 was at 437k. The week prior to that was about 300k. I don't want to project too much from what could be a temporary increase at this point, so I'm still putting a bit more weight on after July 1. But if over 393k cases are maintained for the next few weeks I'll reverse and put more weight on May to June.

Update. This question is dominated by India and, to a lesser extent, Bangladesh. I expect all other countries in the region to add ~0.1M or at most ~0.2M cases by April 30. If cases in India and Bangladesh continue to grow at their same exponential rate, then the region will see just over 20M cases by April 30. I think that's most likely. But the forecast is so tight that I'm going to assign some greater probability to the next bin, thanks to the sage advice of @SE_Meyer, in case growth in India slows down at all.

Update 3/29: 
India, and to a far lesser extent Bangladesh, are driving cases in this region. 
Countries besides India and Indonesia currently contribute about 6.1k cases/day. I'm excluding the Philippines now, as I had erroneously included it; thanks to @SE_Meyer for pointing this out. Then these other countries are likely to contribute at most 0.2M additional cases to the total by the end of April. I'll count on 0.1M.
Then need 5.3M more cases to get to 20M by April 30.
It's a very tight forecast, but assuming growth continues unabated, India and Bangladesh will together contribute about 5.7M additional cases by April 30, so that SE Asia will get to 20M cases by April 30. 
I don't see any significant reason why growth will slow down. However, if growth appears to slow down at some point, this forecast will need to be updated. ***** Cases in WHO Southeast Asia region are currently at 14.6M and are dominated by India, with contributions from the Philippines, Indonesia and, increasingly, Bangladesh. The Philippines may be able to reverse its rise in cases/day; Indonesia may soon see a rise in cases/day. I suspect Bangladesh is likely to see an ongoing increase, and potentially an explosion in cases. It's not clear to me whether India will be able to control the growth in cases/day because of pandemic fatigue and the rise of variants; many may be coming to accept one more infectious disease, in a country in which infectious diseases continue to cause an enormous disease burden. In short, I don't see case growth in India or Bangladesh slowing down appreciably in the near term, but the growth in cases in some other countries, such as the Philippines, might be more likely to slow.  5.4M cases more to get to 20M.
Suppose countries beside India and Bangladesh contribute, conservatively, 0.5M to 1M cases by April 30. 
Then need ~4.5 to 5M from India and Bangladesh in 33 days, or average 136k/day to 152k/day.  Currently, India at 53.2k/day, Bangladesh at 3.3k/day, with doubling times of ~12 and ~9 days, respectively.
Projecting exponential growth in cases/day for India and Bangladesh separately, they will add 5.7M or 38.7M cases by April 30 or May 31, respectively.
So, I think it's possible that the region will reach 20M cases by April 30. It all depends on whether the numbers of cases/day in these countries continue to grow exponentially and at least as quickly as they are now. And it's not clear to me what will slow them down. Seasonality might a bit. Slowing case numbers always lag 1+ weeks behind policy changes, so policies/behaviors would have to change soon to have an impact on this forecast.
95 days and need to stay under 56k cases a day. Currently they look to be above that. However it's hard to say if they'll stay over 56k cases for long. Lots of uncertainty.
103 days to go for bin 5, 5869000 cases missing.  That´s only an average of 57K per day, and currently we´re at 49K, trend up. This is definitely NOT 100% bin 5 anymore.

Haven't done the numbers on this one in a while. Currently there is 106 days between now and 1 July. The current number of cases is 13,986,486, so that leaves 6,013,514 to get to 20,000,000. The daily average would have to be 56,731.264 cases per day to reach 20,000,000 by 1 July. It does appear as though case numbers have gone up a bit since last time I looked, but they are still around the mid 30,000 range, so they would need to go up quite a bit by then. Each day that goes by without reaching the average needed to get there will make the average needed go up. While it is possible, I don't think it is very likely since most of these countries are outstanding at keeping their numbers down with mitigation techniques.
India's second wave is just beginning.

The daily infection rates do not point to a third wave occuring soon, since they are recessing further.
With the current (last two weeks) rate, it would require another 397 days from today to reach the 20 million mark. Even with a steep rise of daily cases in the close future, 20 million cases will not be reached before 01 July.

13.7m cases. 6.3m to go
Current reporting steady around 25k.  
Need flat 50k per day to reach 20m by end June.  never say never, so leaving 1pc on June.
At current rates it looks to be Q4, 21 at the earliest.

Cases have not been rising too fast in the past three months, which makes a second wave during the next 9 weeks less likely. However, the possibility still remains and the rationale still stands to draw analogies from other regions, which saw a second wave 7 months after the first.
Following a straight line of infections rates in the region, 20 million cases would not be hit before September. The argument for that is the growing (but still relatively small) efforts of vaccination.

6.8m to go.
Current rate about 25k per day.  This would take 200 plus days.  
Unless huge upsurge then no chance before July.

based on the current number of cases (12,568,148 on 1/30) and current average rates of increase (28465 daily) that puts it way past after July, 21.  Luckily the rates have been decreasing over time.  My math based on just last 2 weeks data puts it in October, 21.
I maintain my forecast because the number of cases / week remained lower than I had estimated at the maximum. It is decreasing slightly each week

1265700 as of yesterday, stable at about 30K new cases per day for a month now. 245 days at the current level (linear approach) to reach 20M. That would be October. And we´ve got vaccines as well as seasonal effects coming up. Shifting from 0-0-0-10-90 to 0-0-0-5-95.

Indonesia looks like it is finally losing control, and is on track to go India's path:
Daily confirmed case rate more than doubled since 09 December 2020 (~five weeks), India was at that point approximately on 16 June 2020.
The main difference: doubling the daily rate in India's case took less than four weeks, starting on 18 May 2020.  What are the prospects?
/further doubling took 17 days (03 July 2020), then 19 days (22 July 2020), then 39 days (30 August 2020), and the peak occurred after a further increase of ~25% and 13 days on 12 September 2020, in India's case
/Will it repeat? Maybe, unless Indonesia will quickly achieve immunization through vaccination, which I doubt, and maybe intervals will just be slightly longer. Indonesia will likely count 300,000 cases over the next 20 days (until 05 February), 750,000 more cases over 25 more days (until 02 March), and maybe as many as 3,000,000 cases for further 50 days until 20 April 2020. The total could thus quintuple to almost 5,000,000 before the third bin is done, but that's a point where any projections start getting blurry. However, starting at 12,400,000 cases for the whole South-East Asia region as of today, it is hard to see how the region could not end up at more than 20m cases by early summer, if Indonesia does not contain the spread immediately.

7.7m to go.  At 50k cases (current rate) per day this would take 154 days. Which would be early June.  assuming summer and continuing reducing average prob longer.  So not before be June at earliest, reducing average likely to push to July.  So upping bin 5.

Cases consistently decreasing over last 6 weeks. The weather will become start becoming warmer from now onwards. One of the major country in this region is India and the trend there is consistently downwards.

To make it past 1 July (170 days from now) they have to average 45k cases per day at current numbers. Currently they're averaging about 30k, so they're on track to not hit the mark by that time. To hit 20 million before May 1 (109 days from now) they would have to average 70.5k cases per day, or double where they are now. Fairly unlikely for that to be the average at this point I would guess. I'm leaning quite a bit toward not before 1 July.

With 7,689,531 cases to go, here is a breakdown of how many average cases per day would be needed for each of the bins that haven’t been resolved already. I almost left out bin 2 because I think it will be impossible to reach 20,000,000 by the date on that bin. I say this because the average cases per day on the last full week posted to WHO is 29,524.2857 cases per day. It would take at least an increase of about 6 times the number of cases seen in the last week to make the total get into bins 2 and 1. At the current case rate average, it will take 260.4 days to reach 20,000,000. This would put us at Wednesday September 9, 2021. Each day that goes by with new case numbers lower than 45,500.183 cases per day causes the number to increase until eventually it will get to a point that it will not be possible to have that much of an increase to be able to reach 20,000,000 by that date, similar to what we are seeing with bins 1-3 right now.  Bin 2 - Before 28 Feb (47 days): 160,607.042 cases per day or more.
Bin 3 - 1 Mar-30 Apr (48-108 days): 160,198.563 - 71,199.361 cases per day.
Bin 4 - 1 May-30 Jun (109-169 days): 70,546.156 - 45,500.183 case per day.
Bin 5 - 1 July (170+ days) 45,232.535 cases per day.

Current trajectory would suggest no holiday wave. Vaccinations are starting to roll out throughout the region and governments have proven effective at clamping down when hotspots crop up. Therefore, I am dramatically raising the possibility of no more waves in the region which would mean at current rates they won't hit 20M until after July.

Currently reporting about 12m cases with about 30k cases per day.  This means it would take about 266 days to get to 20m.  
To get to 20m by end June is 44k cases per day and to get there by end April it would be 66k cases per day.
Even assuming a doubling of current cases End of April is difficult so splitting forecast for bins 4 and 5.

At the current rate, it appears it will not reach 20,000,000 before August 13th. If it speeds up any I will need to readjust, but it seems to be slowing down more currently. As we get toward the summer months it should slow even further, so if there is another spike, it likely will not be enough to get to 20,000,000 before it slows way down again.
While the disease is still spreading, it is not currently spreading as quickly as it is in Western countries. I think it will spread even more slowly with the advent of the vaccines.

The countries of the SEAR region, ordered by their actual and perceived potential impact on the pandemic in the region:
India   10,031,223 (+26,624) Indonesia 657,984 (+7,751)
Bangladesh 499,560 (+1,267)
Nepal 253,184 (+710)
Myanmar 114,198 (+1,116)
Sri Lanka 36,049 (+662)
Thailand 4,331 (+34)
Bhutan 446 (+3)
Maldives 13,474 (+30)
Timor-Leste 31 (unch) North Korea (no (reliable) figures) India is by far the most important factor and, together with Indonesia and Bangladesh, determines the future of the virus in that region. India has succeeded in suppressing the virus and bringing down the day count from 96k on 18 September 2020 to roughly 26.5k. It has thus far not seen a second spike, which can have several reasons (successful public health policy, including large-scale vaccine trials and hygiene, herd immunity by a large portion of undetected infections, regionally contained outbreaks).  If India will have a second surge of, say, 50k cases per day, it will easily bring up the region's total to 65k to 75k per day, depending on the fate of the others combined.
Bangladesh has already had a small second spike recently but obviously managed to suppress it early.
Indonesia is a big question mark, as it has a huge population with difficult, varying "situations" of public health (urban vs rural population). So far, the pandemic has not been suppressed, but it has not spread without bounds either. Maybe Indonesia benefits from the geographical structure being located on a variety of islands, which makes it easier to contain any outbreak regionally, unless it strikes a metropolitan area. However, Indonesia always appears to be on the brink of a significant acceleration.
In Myanmar, Sri Lanka and Thailand the pandemic seems to be on the rise (again), but so far on a manageable level.
In total, a daily count of 50,000 new cases (20 Dec 2020: 38,197) would definitely spell problems in at least one of the crucial countries and indicates that a revision of the forecast will be necessary, probably towards the third bin "Between 1 March 2021 and 30 April 2021".
Counter measures and vaccines will slow down the trend next year onwards plus the phenomena of virus will gone naturally !

Currently the average for the last few days is now down to about 35,500. To get to 20,000,000, there still needs to be 8,531,894 more cases. As the rate seems to be continuing to slow, I will continue to shift my response, but at 35,500 per day, it would take until Friday, 13 August. There is always the potential for a surge in cases again, but it seems to me that this area is doing well in handling surges and getting numbers back down. I will update again in a few weeks.

Adjusting due to slowing of the numbers. Averaging 40,367 a day right now for the last two days, which will take 219 days to reach 20,000,000. This will mean that it will not happen before 15 July at the current rate, but the numbers may just be a reflection of the weekend. If it slows more, I will likely go all in on the last bin.
The rate appears to be slowing still, which means that it is more likely to end up in the later two bins.

Major portion of the cases in South East Asia are in India. India has gone past its small holiday bump and is again trending downwards. Linear extrapolation will put the date in bin 4 but when has corona virus been loyal to linear extrapolation!!
Oxford vaccine just yesterday applied for emergency approval in India. I am betting that India's average cases over next 3 months will be less than what it is today. Hence putting most weight in bin 5

Based on @Rohan1965 , 10.3M now with 350k cases per week
Let's say 12M Jan 1st
14.5M Feb 1st
17M March 1st
18M April 1st
19M May 1st
19.8M June 1st

Currently at 10.3m with 350k new cases each week. Estimate 12m by 1 January, 15m 1st February, 18m 1st March and 20m by 15th March.
See WHO situation reports
https://www.who.int/publications/m/item/weekly-epidemiological-update---24-november-2020

At a rate of 50,000 cases a day, this would take until June 2 (9,074,718 cases to go, divided by 50,000 =181.49 days), however, the numbers seem to be going down over the last 7 days. The average number for the last 7 days is 49,188. If this means that it will take 184.49 days to reach 20,000,000. If the numbers slow down further, or speed up, there is still a cushion on both sides for it to fall into "bin 4". I do expect the case rate to go up in the coming months, and then fall off significantly over the next few months as we move into summer weather. IT is very difficult to determine future numbers based off of a base rate that does not include the potential for exponential increases, however, I am going to estimate with high confidence that it will be sometime in "bin 4" for now based off of the daily average (which should account for an upswing during flu season, and a downswing in the warmer months) and update as needed.

Base scenario: with current daily numbers on average for the rest of the duration it would be somewhere between bins 4 and 5. 
Other possible scenarios: 
- getting out of control (would be bins 1-3; very, very unlikely in Asia)
- current trend downwards to continue (=bin 5)
- vaccines helping to further reduce numbers (=bin 5)

Having passed the first wave of infections, it is highly likely that a second wave will hit the region.
Drawing from the experiences of other regions, the second wave typically has its peak six to seven months after the first. This would be between March and April 2021. Since over half of the 20 million cases have been reported already, a good chance remains that the 20 million mark could be hit even before the peak of the second wave.
In case an effective vaccine should be found and widely distributed in the first months of 2021 esp. in India, Bangladesh and Indonesia - which is unlikely - the mark of 20 million cases could be hit between May and June.

It is very likely that the South-East Asia region will experience a serious second wave with more than 100,000 new cases per day from the beginning of February 2021, which would total around 6mn additional cases alone.

They have already crossed 10 million cases. Interestingly their peak did not come at the beginning of covid but rather throughout September where they had quite a few days of over 100,000 cases. This is important because it shows they had a rise even with all of the measures and knowledge we had. Lately they have gotten it down to under 55k a day. If we use 60k as our average to give some cushion for randomly high weeks we will hit another ten million in 5 and a half months (167 days). That would mean the beginning of May. I am unsure about how a vaccine in the beginning of 2021 will alter these numbers so I am putting more weight on it being after May rather than before. If they were able to keep their average at 50,000 a day they would keep it under ten million until 200 days or around 6.7 months still before July.

Based on WHO data on South East Asia. Lots of underreporting because of low testing capability and low knowledge of the virus among the SEA population in general, may skew the actual number of cases. Currently the counted cases for the region are 9.9 million and the number of confirmed cases is decreasting and have been for the last month which was the high peak of this year.
Improved PPE and the possibility of a vaccine is going to slow down the spread.

Seems to me there are 3 scenarios (outlined below). 
Due to changing seasons, challenges in infrastructure in the region, and lack of vaccine, I don't think the region will continue to decline too much further making scenario 1 unlikely.
I don't think that the region is going to see a second wave as severe as the first, either, though I may be wrong, which is why I give this scenario a rather high probability at this time.
I do feel that the region will hold (roughly) steady in terms of new cases. 
This would put the region on a path to 20M by about Mid-May, hence giving the probability of the May-June option the highest allocation. (1) "Happy Case" - continued gradual decline
If cases continue to decline at the average rate of about 0.7% per day, the area will not hit 20M cases before 1 July (2) "Steady State"
If cases roughly stabilize where they are now, and don't swing much, region will reach 20M cases by around Mid-May. This is extremely rough but assumes that trend moves up and down will generally cancel one another out (3) Second Wave
If we see a growth and then fall in cases roughly similar to what the region saw from the end of July to present, the region could hit 20M cases by around the beginning of April.

It’s winter in a few Asian countries, which should result in a slight uptick in cases. Plus, as India eases lockdown slightly, their cases will rise. So, I think we will see 20m cases hit 44 days from now, ie, almost exactly on Christmas Day 2020.
Conspiracy of countries who hate USA and to bring down Trump!

I can't find any curves for previous epidemics in the region. I was looking for seasonal influences. The main question at the moment is whether the curve will stay steady, or if there is a risk of a upward trend. Main risks, to my mind, are holidays with big gatherings, weather, and demographics. SE Asia is demographically one of  the youngest places in the world, so less risk there. Open to info on holidays and weather/seasonal influences, if anyone has good sources. *** also interested in influence of population density to infection.

If they maintained 50,000 cases a day it wouldn't be until around May. There's a decent chance cases could jump up between now and then as seen in other regions, or they could continue on a steady decline. If cases averaged double or 100,000 a day starting now they would hit 20 million in late February. But that's a pretty significant jump and assumes an instant doubling, so I think February is unlikely. I lean a little bit toward them not reaching 20 million in the timeframe.

South East Asia currently has about 9.7 million confirmed cases. The rate of infection is slowly dropping but I'd anticipate an increase over public holidays, especially the different New Year celebrations (January and February). With Christmas being the end of December, we might get more infections in the final week of 2020, but I don't think a high percentage of new infections will be confirmed over Christmas. Many governments may also want to report the figures later to not appear like a spike took place over any celebrations, so as to spare the short term economic shock of cancelling celebrations.

9M so far... 11M to go. 
9 months passed (inclusive of Feb). 8 months to go. Assuming warmer weather and vaccine, and tight restrictions, 20M will not be reached till July.
